10.11.text: >> Warwick Mansell: Our final speaker is Jan.

13.37.text:
>> Jan Dubiel: I’m still reeling a bit from
the thought of Michael Gove and Carol Dweck

24.32.text:
in the same room, I can feel a Radio 4 play
coming up!

30.62.text:
>> Okay, it’s quite interesting being at
the end because you get to pick up what the

35.53.text:
main themes are, and we’ve had some quite
contrasting views of where we see assessment.

38.57.text:
I want to focus mostly on the idea of baseline,
partly because that’s my area of expertise

44.17.text:
and, partly I think in some senses that’s
the most contentious, but the most important

49.14.text:
thing, most important stuff in early years,
is what I go from.

55.70.text:
>> So, a couple of things to start with. One
is let’s distinguish carefully between the

60.79.text:
words assessment and testing. They’re essentially
different activities and the words do get

67.19.text:
used interchangeably and they’re very different.
Assessment, as Alison and myself as practitioners

70.91.text:
would tell you, is an ongoing pedagogical
behaviour. As teachers you are constantly

78.41.text:
assessing children, you are constantly pulling
out information from what they say, what they

83.22.text:
do and what they don’t do which informs
your interactions, informs your planning,

86.99.text:
informs your understanding of them as a learner,
in terms of what they know, how they know

91.47.text:
it, how they utilise that learning and so
on. You make somewhere between two and 10,000

96.80.text:
decisions every day. Early years practitioners
certainly have round about 1,000 interactions

101.80.text:
with their children, each of those interactions
is a decision based on how you’ve assessed

107.88.text:
those children to start with. So that idea
of assessment, I think we have to define that

113.09.text:
out as much broader. Secondly, my favourite
baseline assessment absolutely, I’m in favour

118.59.text:
of it for several reasons. One, practitioners
in early years doing it anyway, you can’t

125.69.text:
be effective as a practitioner, as a teacher,
unless you have an understanding of that child

132.89.text:
as the learner.
>> So, the idea of introducing a baseline

135.48.text:
assessment is a bit of a misnomer in a way.
There isn’t a practitioner in the land in

140.34.text:
early (years), certainly in Reception, who
doesn’t undertake some form of on-entry

145.91.text:
>> So what baseline does is formalise and
articulate and quantify in a sense that process.

153.11.text:
So the questions are two key questions really
and, I’m always reminded of a quote that

157.36.text:
Einstein had on his wall - I don’t think
it’s his quote himself but he had it on

163.82.text:
his wall - and it’s that “what counts
can’t always be counted; what can be counted

171.77.text:
doesn’t always count”. I don’t think
he was necessarily referring to early years

179.28.text:
assessments, but you do wonder because that
seems to relate directly to the challenges

186.41.text:
and change we face. So there are two key questions
in baseline assessment and one of them isn’t

191.82.text:
“should we have it?”; absolutely, because
it exists already. The first question is what

196.66.text:
we assess, what is significant about children’s
learning on entry to Reception, what are the

203.85.text:
things that really matter in terms of them
as learners and in terms of that long term

209.46.text:
projection and that trajectory that we need
to be accountable for. 85% of life time neurological

216.38.text:
connections are made by the time children
leave Reception. The fundamentals of all learning

222.30.text:
are imbedding during that early years’ experience,
so getting it right in early years really,

229.40.text:
>> So what are the things that matter, well
it’s not the things that are easy to count.

233.30.text:
It’s not, dare I say it, how many phonics
they know, how high they can count, whether

237.91.text:
or not they apparently can push their chairs
under the table, whether or not they can stand

242.52.text:
in a straight line or sit in a circle and
some of the other things. Whether or not they

246.44.text:
can count carrots or say the word frigglejang
and some of the other nonsense that’s out

249.59.text:
there. I’m not making that up as I’m sure
we’ll find out in a minute! What’s significant

256.00.text:
about children’s learning and Carol Dweck’s
work and, again I’m still reeling from this,

259.87.text:
is fundamental in this. It’s about how they
act as learners, it’s about their learning

266.07.text:
behaviours. In the EYFS we have something
called the characteristics of effective learning

271.86.text:
which look a things like persistence, tenacity,
ability to make connections, creativity, communication,

275.53.text:
those sorts of things, these are lifelong
skills. If we’re looking at assessment and

280.48.text:
we’re looking at what makes these children
effective learners and then how we support

286.33.text:
them – and I’ll come to that in a minute
– then we have to look very carefully at

289.53.text:
what matters and the things that matter aren’t
always the things that are easy to measure;

294.87.text: in fact the opposite is often true.

297.09.text:
>> Second question we have to ask is how we
get that information, what’s the methodology

301.73.text:
we use. Again, learning in early years, and
I spent 15 years as a nursery, reception and

309.12.text:
year one teacher, is very very untidy, it’s
very messy, it’s very surreal a lot of the

315.58.text:
time! You need a good sense of humour and
a very strong stomach to be an early years

320.86.text:
practitioner. Some of the things that go on,
you sit at home and think did that really

325.23.text:
happen or was I tripping or hallucinating.
So, getting to the point of that and understanding

331.20.text:
what’s real in that is a very complex process
and now we’ve got a debate raging, as we’ve

337.19.text:
had since the beginning of time between observational
based assessment and testing and that distinction

344.53.text:
is a critical one. When you test very young
children it’s wrong to say you don’t get

351.27.text:
information. You do get information, but you
get very narrow specific, fairly pointless

356.90.text:
and useless information. You get information
of what a child does in response to an adult,

362.91.text:
that’s not the same as real learning. An
observation assessment which is embedding

366.93.text:
as part of the EYFS has been part of a long
tradition of early years practice that’s

372.31.text:
since the turn of the previous century and
Margaret McMillan in the Deptford nursery

375.90.text:
schools, is about watching how children use
their learning, how children applies those

381.74.text:
knowledge skills, those learning behaviours,
what they act like, particularly in what we

387.49.text:
might describe as a play context, or a self-initiated
context. So we have a question here about

391.86.text:
we get that information? Do we sit children
down and text them, because that’s easy

396.92.text:
even though information is inauthentic, fairly
spurious, fairly unconnected to anything and

401.88.text:
probably inaccurate or, do we take that time
to observe those key behaviours, those significant

411.01.text:
>> And, finally, Government policy at the
moment seems to be driving this false dichomotomy

416.40.text:
between formative and summative assessment.
Formative assessment is all over the consultation,

422.10.text:
it’s what teachers do all the time, very
much what I said at the beginning. Then there’s

427.41.text:
summative assessment which is there for accountability.
Do I dispute accountability? Absolutely not,

431.94.text:
of course we’re accountable for those children
but the measures we use and the assessments

437.21.text:
we use have to derive from that ongoing assessment
because if you’re assessing for any other

443.53.text:
purpose that had to support that child’s
learning you are using valuable time as a

448.87.text:
practitioner to do something that isn’t
to directly impact on that learner. So I want

455.49.text:
to throw those out as questions, or as challenges,
and I’ll stop. I think my five minutes is

it gives us three very contrasting but complimentary

wouldn’t be below and I imagine it would

Government reports, while the conversation

Alison, what you’re doing in your school

if you could take where you were going to

why I carry on doing what I’m doing because

I think that there’s a real challenge for

806.87.text:
our gift, within classrooms to either allow

813.33.text:
or to resist that and say, well we can take

baseline level for example and see it as it’s

is about school performance so we’ll put

as a cohort measure. The likelihood however

Ofsted are about to call will say, what was

835.26.text:
what it? It was pretty bad wasn’t it? Yeah,
really really bad, it really was but how much

838.57.text:
we done in the first year and how am I going

841.96.text:
well perhaps we ought to measure it again.
That’s my worry that we lead ourselves,

845.69.text:
that we choose as a profession to go into
a test based culture, because we’re frightened

850.66.text:
of the accountability regime. We don’t have
to do that however, so for example in our

school at the moment we use the EYFS baseline,

children which is through observation, but
we are at the moment talking to other providers

who are developing test materials in order

875.43.text:
resources tell us, in order that we can take
a balanced view rather than saying, if it’s

882.51.text:
tested that result must be more important
than what I know by working with this child

887.20.text:
day in day out. So I think everything has
to be informed by professionalism and the

892.59.text:
reason that I have to leave at 10am and go
off to something else is because I’m working

896.96.text:
very hard to try and move the profession into
the space where we actually can be above politics,

902.53.text:
where we can be much more informed about our
practice and we have a voice saying we do

906.84.text:
this in our school because we know this works
because this is the evidence that tells us

912.08.text:
>> So it’s got to be about rigour, I think
we have to subvert the agenda, we have to

920.38.text:
work within it and when I told you at the
beginning bout Michael Gove mentioning Carol

Dweck’s work, I’m encouraged by that because

isn’t fixed that runs counter to the reports

who’s one of the Secretary of State’s

to suggest – well, he did suggest in his

that he thought it would be a jolly good idea

very accurately. One then assumes that the

because obviously the fantastically inspiring

that are out there, how realistic is it really

be a head teacher. When I met with Warwick

we’re looking at this. I think there are

big problems but in terms of shaping policy,

Advisory Teacher is absolutely that use of
